awd_titl_txt: QRM: Understanding the Mechanical Design of Natural Cellular Materials via a Multiscale Quantitative Structural Representation
awd_abstract_narration:
Many biological materials systems, such as wood, bones, sponges, and sea urchins, utilize cellular structures for simultaneous mechanical function and weight saving. Similarly,  engineering cellular solids with lightweight design and mechanical efficiency, have become increasingly favored for applications in energy, infrastructure, aerospace, biomedical, and the automotive vehicle industries. While many engineering cellular materials are manufactured to have either completely stochastic or periodic lattices, natural cellular materials often exhibit complex three-dimensional cellular designs with controlled structural morphologies at multiple length scales. This is believed to contribute to their remarkable mechanical robustness, especially considering their mechanically weak or soft constituents. This award will support a fundamental study to elucidate the multi-scale structural basis of the high-performance natural cellular materials, through an integrated multi-disciplinary effort involving materials science and engineering, mechanical engineering, computer vision, and data science. The insights gained from natural cellular materials will provide important guidance in the design and manufacturing of engineering cellular materials, deepen our understanding of structural cellular solids, and provide insights for the design and fabrication of advanced lightweight materials and structures, with potential benefits to US Manufacturing and Infrastructure sectors.

This work will establish a quantitative, comprehensive, and efficient structural representation scheme for the multi-scale cellular network of highly porous structures found in natural systems. The researchers will study the bioceramic cellular structure of sea urchin spines as a testbed system, and multiscale structural representations will elucidate fundamental understanding of their remarkable mechanical robustness and damage tolerance. The work will address the challenges of representing complex, hierarchical cellular structures via three major innovations, including high-resolution tomography imaging and adaptive compressive data processing, multi-scale representation of the cellular structure (individual strut and node level, local unit-cell level, and global cellular network level), and in-silico "regrowth" of bio-inspired cellular structures with morphological control at multiple length scales. The research team will further validate the multi-level cellular structural representation through systematic finite element simulations coupled with synchrotron imaging-based in-situ mechanical testing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The major goal of this project was to develop a quantitative framework to represent and analyze the multiscale 3D structure for biological ceramic cellular materials, and to further understand the structure-mechanical property relationship of this class of materials. This work was motivated by the challenges to develop damage tolerant ceramic porous materials, while natural ceramic cellular solids often exhibit remarkable resistance to damage and fracture. The project utilized sea urchin spines as a primary model system and later expanded to systems such as cuttlebone and starfish ossicles, which demonstrate rich structural features and variations across multiple length scales and remarkable damage tolerance. The efforts of this project have resulted in the development of a multi-scale cellular network representation pipeline, quantitative network description of sea urchin spines’ bicontinuous porous structures, quantification of crack formation and damage evolution in understanding the deformation mechanisms of sea urchin spines, and discovery of structural features and corresponding mechanical design strategies in other bioceramic cellular structures such as cuttlebone and starfish ossicles. We revealed that in sea urchin spines, the combination of bending-induced microfracture of branches and subsequent local jamming of fractured fragments facilitated by the small throat openings in the cellular network leads to the progress formation and growth of densified damage bands. This leads to the sea urchin spines’ high plateau stress during compression similar to metallic and polymeric cellular solids. The outcome of this project will have the impact to expand our current knowledge of structural design of biological porous materials, bio-mimic material design, and mechanical analysis of cellular solids.

Broader Impact: Echindoerms (such as sea urchins and starfish) produce a variety of complex bicontinuous porous structural elements through biologically controlled mineralization processes, such as the sharp spines and dome-shaped body in sea urchins. Despite the brittle biomineral constituent (calcite), these structures exhibit simultaneous high strength and damage tolerance, which is in stark contrast to the engineering ceramic foams. With the ultimate goal to understand the structural design principles in these natural ceramic cellular materials, the award supported a collaboration between PI Ling Li’s lab in Mechanical Engineering and co-PI Yunhui Zhu’s lab in Electrical and Computer Engineering at Virginia Tech. This collaborative work led to the development of several micro-CT (in-situ) imaging-based characterization and analysis algorithms, a multiscale cellular network representation and analysis algorithm, and a machine learning-based pipeline for detecting and analyzing the damage evolution in bioceramic cellular materials. These protocols can be utilized to analyze both biological and synthetic ceramic cellular materials. This grant also contributed to the training of a diverse, competitive STEM workforce, including four Ph.D. students in total (in particular, Ting Yang and Ziling Wu successfully graduated based on the work supported by this award and are now both working at MIT as postdoctoral fellows), post-doc (Dr. Zian Jia, in progress), and more than 10 undergraduate students. Among these undergraduates, two continue pursuing their PhDs and one is working towards his M.S. degree in PI Ling Li’s lab. With the support from the grant, both PIs engaged the diverse educational outreach efforts both within and outside campus, including outreach activities through the C-Tech2 program at Virginia Tech, guest lectures, and public lectures. In addition, several works resulted from this award have been reported by many media outlets, including ScienceDaily, Yahoo News, VT New, Phys.ORG, etc. 

Products: The research team has published 11 papers from this award so far (with more being under review and to be submitted soon). These publications include articles in Acta Biomaterialia, PNAS, Advanced Materials, Advanced Science, etc. In particular, the cellular network analysis developed under this award contributed to the discovery of the first biomineralized diamond triply periodic minimal surface structure found in starfish skeletal elements, which has been published in Science as a cover article. Also as part of this project, the team developed an a multiscale 3D cellular network analysis pipeline, which allows the representation and analysis of the biological cellular structures such as stereom at three different length scales, including individual branch and node level, local cellular level, and global network level (the subject published as a two-paper series in Acta Biomaterialia). This award also resulted in 10 conference proceedings, more than 10 invited talks in conferences, workshops, and course guest lectures. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/28/2022
Modified by: Ling Li
